name: Sudan
currentCrisisSummary:
Sudan is engulfed in a brutal civil war between two **predatory military factions** (SAF & RSF), unleashing the **world's largest displacement crisis** and **mass famine**. The conflict has triggered widespread atrocities and renewed **ethnic cleansing in Darfur**, a region historically marginalised since the **colonial era**.

The warring elites compete for control of **economic spoils** (gold, land, external patronage), inflicting a **catastrophic humanitarian collapse**. International agencies warn of worsening conditions, with **acute hunger affecting millions**, collapsing health systems, and **deliberate obstruction of aid**. This war is not merely internal; it is **actively sustained by external actors (like the UAE)**, transnational arms flows, and the **failure of international systems** to enforce accountability or halt the violence.

colonialRoot.legacy:
British colonial governance in Sudan employed a classic divide-and-rule strategy, concentrating power in the 'Arab' riverine north while marginalising peripheral regions like Darfur and Kordofan. This structural inequality institutionalised regional grievance and set the groundwork for recurring rebellions and civil wars.

By privileging the centre and denying development to the margins, colonial rule created a centralised, extractive state whose control over resources and institutions became the prize of military competition post-independence.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberalism and the Roots of Revolution
historicalContext.description: Omar al-Bashir's 30-year rule, while Islamist and militaristic, also embraced a harsh neoliberal economic model. Under pressure from US sanctions and the IMF, his regime privatised state assets, slashed subsidies, and encouraged large-scale 'land grabs' by foreign investors, particularly from the Gulf. This policy of austerity and resource extraction enriched a small elite while impoverishing the population. The 2019 revolution was triggered by bread price hikes, a direct result of these long-standing neoliberal policies. Tragically, the subsequent transitional government was itself pressured by Western donors into a rapid 'shock therapy' program, whose painful economic consequences weakened its popular standing and contributed to the success of the 2021 military coup.

historicalContext.title: Rival Military Economic Models
historicalContext.description:
The current war is a breakdown of an entrenched military elite order. The SAF represents the old guard's hold on formal sectors (bureaucracy, security, agriculture), whereas the RSF acts as a more entrepreneurial, informal military-economic actor controlling gold, illicit trade routes and private paramilitary roles. Both compete over the spoils of Sudan â€” land, mining, agriculture, and foreign leasing arrangements.

This struggle is not new: economic control, militia patronage and resource extraction have long been central to Sudanese elite survival, with successive regimes co-opted by foreign capital and external actors seeking influence.

The 2021 military coup was a counter-revolution against popular pressure to dismantle the military's economic empire. The RSF is backed by regional states, notably the UAE, which is accused of providing arms, financial support and logistical backing. These external actors seek influence, access to Sudanese gold, agricultural land and control of strategic Red Sea ports.

Recent investigative reports document advanced weapons, drone systems and heavy artillery traced to external supply chains used by the RSF â€” raising credible allegations of external complicity in sustaining, and escalating, Sudan's war.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Multiple international and regional legal processes are underway or proposed. Sudan has filed claims and complaints alleging external complicity in grave abuses. UN Security Council expert panels, human-rights organisations and the ICC are documenting war crimes, crimes against humanity and atrocity patterns committed by both SAF and RSF. The challenge is enforcing accountability in a conflict with shifting frontlines, obstructed access and powerful external proxies; protecting witnesses, securing evidence and dismantling economic networks that enable conflict profiteering are central to any credible justice effort.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands killed in direct combat; far more dying from **starvation and disease caused by the warring parties' blockades and destruction.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 30 million people require aid due to the **nationwide collapse inflicted by the military factions' war for power and resources.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Famine Conditions
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 24 million face acute hunger, with famine conditions emerging as **warring parties weaponise food access and destroy agriculture.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement Catastrophe
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 12 million internally displaced (world's largest crisis), forcibly uprooted by **SAF/RSF violence, including ethnic cleansing campaigns.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugee Exodus
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 4 million refugees driven abroad since 2023 by the **brutality of the conflict and lack of any safe haven.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Most health facilities non-functional due to **direct attacks, looting by warring factions, and lack of supplies caused by the conflict.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions lack safe water as **infrastructure is destroyed or neglected due to the war**, fuelling cholera outbreaks.

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Denied
humanitarianImpact.description: Up to 19 million children denied education as schools are **damaged, occupied by fighters, or inaccessible due to displacement.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Deepening Poverty
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions pushed into extreme poverty by the **war's destruction of livelihoods, infrastructure, and the formal economy.**

timeline.event: **Anglo-Egyptian Condominium**: British colonial rule imposed structures that privileged the 'Arab' north and marginalised peripheries like Darfur and Kordofan, embedding regional inequality.
**Independence**: Sudan gains independence, inheriting a centralised state structure that concentrated power and resources in the north.

**Bashir's Islamist Coup**: Omar al-Bashir seizes power. His 30-year rule combines military and Islamist control with harsh neoliberal policies, deploying proxy militias to suppress rebellious, economically marginalised peripheries.

**Darfur Conflict / Genocide**: The Bashir government deploys Janjaweed militias in Darfur to crush rebellions; mass atrocities and ethnic cleansing follow. The RSF is a later institutional successor to these militias.
**Sudanese Revolution**: Triggered by rising bread prices after decades of neoliberal austerity, a mass popular uprising topples Bashir, demanding the dismantling of the military-economic complex.
**Military Coup**: Generals al-Burhan and Hemedti (RSF) remove the transitional civilian government to protect their economic and security interests.
**Civil War Breaks Out**: The SAF-RSF alliance fractures into full-blown war. Territorial control, air and drone bombardments, sieges and proxy warfare spread across Sudan.

**Sieges, Famine & Cruelty in Darfur**: El Fasher and Darfur camps face siege, repeated drone and artillery attacks, famine conditions, mass displacement and reported massacres in camps such as Zamzam and Abu Shouk.

donate.description: A diaspora-led network delivering medical and humanitarian support through local Emergency Response Rooms and health services.
Providing protection, shelter and core relief support to millions of refugees and internally displaced people inside Sudan and across its borders.
Delivers emergency protection, education, and mental health support to children and families displaced by the ongoing civil war.
At the front lines of Sudan's hunger crisis, WFP provides life-saving food and nutrition support across conflict-affected regions.

advocacy: Press for an international arms embargo targeting both the SAF and RSF and for sanctions on external backers such as the UAE and others complicit in sustaining the war.
Demand divestment from companies linked to the Sudanese war economy, including gold trade, land deals and military supply chains.
Support ICC prosecutions and UN accountability processes for genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur and other conflict zones.
Advocate for protected humanitarian corridors, ceasefires and politically negotiated transitions that place civilians' safety and governance reform at the centre.
Push for restoration and reinvestment in Sudan's public services, infrastructure and social safety nets in a post-conflict future.
